Article Title: Mark Zuckerberg, Sam Atlman and other tech leaders who plan to attend Donald Trump’s inauguration
Article Text:
At least three CEOs will attend the inauguration

Other tech leaders that may attend Trump’s inauguration

Several prominent tech leaders have already met President-elect Donald Trump and now a number of them are set to attend Donald Trump’s inauguration this month, a report has said. This may signal the industry's efforts to strengthen ties with Trump as he returns to the White House.According to a report by Bloomberg, Mark Zuckerberg , the CEO of Facebook-parent company Meta , intends to be present, as confirmed by a source familiar with the matter. Zuckerberg has reportedly met with Trump two times ahead of him assuming office as the President of the US. OpenAI CEO Sam Altman also plans to attend the swearing-in ceremony on January 20, according to a company spokesperson. Previous reports have said that Altman is finding it difficult to meet the President-elect because of Elon Musk , who is purportedly stationed as a gatekeeper. Anyone who wants to meet Trump has to go through Musk, reports claimed. Uber CEO Dara Khosrowshahi will participate in some of the surrounding festivities, according to the company. Uber also plans to co-host an inauguration party in Washington with Elon Musk’s X social media firm and The Free Press, a media company, Bloomberg said.In addition to Altman, OpenAI president Greg Brockman and chief product officer Kevin Weil also plan to attend the inauguration, as told by a company spokesperson to the publication. Musk is also likely to attend, given his close relationship with Trump.Various tech leaders, such as Google CEO Sundar Pichai, Apple chief executive Tim Cook and Amazon founder Jeff Bezos have reportedly met with Trump after his win in the US Presidential elections.Meta and Amazon have pledged to donate $1 million to Trump’s inauguration fund, meanwhile, Altman has personally donated $1 million to the fund.
Article Summary: Mark Zuckerberg, the CEO of Facebook-parent company Meta, intends to be present, as confirmed by a source familiar with the matter. OpenAI CEO Sam Altman also plans to attend the swearing-in ceremony on January 20. Uber CEO Dara Khosrowshahi will participate in some of the surrounding festivities, according to the company.

Article Title: Elon Musk gets US government support in what he called “illegal” conversion from Microsoft and ChatGPT maker OpenAI
Article Text:

Elon Musk vs Sam Altman

US antitrust regulators have reportedly backed part of Elon Musk 's argument in his legal battle to prevent OpenAI from restructuring as a for-profit company. According to a report by Bloomberg, in a court filing, the Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) argued that overlapping board memberships can negatively impact competition, even after a director resigns. Hoffman has publicly criticized FTC Chair Lina Khan, calling for her removal.Musk initially sued OpenAI in state court, then dropped and refiled the case in federal court. He claims OpenAI breached its original non-profit mission by accepting billions in funding from Microsoft starting in 2019 and argues that immediate court intervention is necessary to prevent OpenAI from dominating the AI market.OpenAI, which declined to comment on the latest filing, has previously defended the legality of Hoffman and Templeton's board positions and dismissed Musk's lawsuit as baseless, claiming he initially supported a more traditional corporate structure for the company.

Article Title: TikTok warns US Supreme Court on ban: If Congress could do this to TikTok, it could ...
Article Text:
During Supreme Court arguments, TikTok warned that a law forcing its sale or ban in the U.S. could set a precedent impacting other companies. Represented by Noel Francisco, TikTok argued the law violates First Amendment free speech. Defending the law, Solicitor General Elizabeth Prelogar emphasized the urgency of national security concerns with a January 19 deadline.

Upset Tiktok content creators

TikTok and its Chinese parent company ByteDance reportedly offered a warning during Supreme Court arguments over a law that would compel the sale of the short-video app or ban it in the United States. According to a report by news agency Reuters, the lawyer representing TikTok warned of broader implications for other companies. Noel Francisco, representing TikTok and ByteDance, argued that: "If Congress could do this to TikTok, it could come after other companies, too."The law, debated by the justices, sets a January 19 deadline for ByteDance to sell the platform or face a ban due to national security concerns. The companies argue that the law violates First Amendment free speech protections and seek at least a delay. Francisco argued that upholding this law could justify similar actions against other companies. He cited the example of AMC theaters, previously Chinese-owned, suggesting Congress could use this precedent to censor or promote specific films.While some justices expressed First Amendment concerns, their questions suggested an inclination to uphold the law. TikTok boasts roughly 170 million U.S. users. Congress passed the measure with bipartisan support in 2024, citing fears of Chinese government espionage and influence operations.Jeffrey Fisher, representing TikTok content creators, reportedly questioned why the law targeted only TikTok and not other Chinese online retailers like Temu, which has 70 million U.S. users. He questioned the logic of singling out TikTok while ignoring other platforms potentially subject to Chinese control.As per the Reuters report, solicitor General Elizabeth Prelogar, defending the law for the Biden administration, emphasized the urgency of the January 19 deadline to force ByteDance's action. She argued that "foreign adversaries" wouldn't willingly relinquish control over a major U.S. communication channel and that the deadline might be the necessary "jolt" for divestiture.A January 19 ban would prevent new TikTok downloads on Apple and Google platforms, though existing users could initially still access the app. However, the app's functionality would degrade over time without ongoing support.The Court also debated whether potential Chinese propaganda or influence campaigns justified the ban. Francisco countered that content manipulation is widespread, citing various U.S. news outlets.There was mention of the possibility of a change in administration affecting the law's enforcement, with the suggestion that a new administration might pursue a different approach. A justice questioned whether the president could simply choose not to enforce the law, to which the Solicitor General acknowledged presidential enforcement discretion. The argument was made that a preliminary injunction could provide "breathing space."
Article Summary: TikTok warned that a law forcing its sale or ban in the U.S. could set a precedent impacting other companies. The law sets a January 19 deadline for ByteDance to sell the platform or face a ban. Congress passed the measure with bipartisan support in 2024, citing fears of Chinese government espionage.

Article Title: Mark Zuckerberg shuts down Meta fact-checking program, replaces it with Community Notes in the US
Article Text: In a significant policy shift, Meta, the parent company of Facebook and Instagram, has announced the end of its third-party fact-checking program in the United States. This move comes as President-elect Donald Trump prepares to take office for a second term.Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg revealed that the company will replace the fact-checking program with a community-based system similar to the " Community Notes " model used by Elon Musk's social platform X. This new approach will allow users to call out potentially misleading posts and provide additional context, rather than relying on independent fact-checking organisations."We're going to get rid of fact-checkers and replace them with community notes similar to X, starting in the US," Zuckerberg said in a video. "We've reached a point where it's just too many mistakes and too much censorship. It's time to get back to our roots around free expression ," he said.Zuckerberg cited the need to prioritise free expression and reduce mistakes in content moderation as reasons for the change. Meta will focus its automated systems on removing high-severity violations and illegal content, such as terrorism and illicit drugs, while reducing proactive scanning for hate speech and other rule-breaking content.

Article Title: Disney, Fox, Warner Bros' Venu Sports streaming plan is Dead: "After careful consideration, we have ...," says the joint statement
Article Text:
What's behind the scrapping of Venu Sports

The Walt Disney Co., Fox Corp. , and Warner Bros. Discovery Inc. have abandoned their plans to launch a joint sports streaming service, Venu Sports , just days after reaching a settlement in a lawsuit that challenged the venture's potential anti-competitive impact.The companies announced the discontinuation of Venu Sports in a joint statement, citing the "ever-changing marketplace" and a desire to "meet the evolving demands of sports fans by focusing on existing products and distribution channels." They also expressed gratitude to the Venu staff and pledged support during the transition.“After careful consideration, we have collectively agreed to discontinue the Venu Sports joint venture and not launch the streaming service,” the companies said in a statement. “In an ever-changing marketplace, we determined that it was best to meet the evolving demands of sports fans by focusing on existing products and distribution channels. We are proud of the work that has been done on Venu to date and grateful to the Venu staff, whom we will support through this transition period,” the statement added.The decision follows a legal challenge initiated by FuboTV Inc. , a sports-focused streaming service, which argued that Venu Sports would stifle competition and harm consumers. FuboTV contended that the joint venture would exclude them from carrying certain key sports channels, potentially forcing them out of business, and would ultimately lead to higher prices for consumers. The U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) also signaled its intention to scrutinize the project for potential antitrust violations.The concept for Venu Sports emerged last year as the three media giants sought to combine their valuable sports content into a single streaming package, targeting viewers who desired access to live sports without traditional cable subscriptions. The proposed service immediately drew opposition, culminating in FuboTV's lawsuit.Despite this settlement, other industry players continued to express concerns. EchoStar Corp. and pay-TV provider DirecTV Inc. submitted a letter to Judge Garnett, arguing that Disney's agreement with FuboTV did not fully address the underlying anti-competitive issues posed by the Venu Sports concept.The abandonment of Venu Sports comes as live sports remains a highly lucrative sector of the television industry. With the ongoing trend of cord-cutting, media companies are actively reassessing how to package and distribute sports content to reach audiences.
Article Summary: Disney, Fox and Warner Bros. announced the discontinuation of Venu Sports in a joint statement. The decision follows a legal challenge initiated by FuboTV Inc. The U.S. Department of Justice also signaled its intention to scrutinize the project for potential antitrust violations.

Article Title: Elon Musk’s X is making it easier for users to identify parody accounts
Article Text:
X plans to make these labels mandatory

Elon Musk-owned social media platform X has announced that it will begin labeling parody and satire accounts to clearly distinguish them from authentic profiles. This move aims to prevent users from mistaking posts from these accounts as genuine statements from the individuals or organisations being spoofed.“We’re rolling out profile labels for parody accounts to clearly distinguish these types of accounts and their content on our platform. We designed these labels to increase transparency and to ensure that users are not deceived into thinking such accounts belong to the entity being parodied. Parody labels will be applied to both posts and accounts on X to clearly demonstrate the source of the content you’re seeing. We’ll share details soon on when the label will become mandatory for parody accounts,” the company said in a post on X.“These accounts, like all accounts on X, must still adhere to the X Rules - particularly our Authenticity policy,” X added, saying that users can report an account if they believe an account is inauthentic or impersonating an entity.The label will be visible on both the account's profile and individual posts. Currently, users can manually add the label in their account settings.“Parody, Fan, and Commentary (PCF) labels are selected by people on X to indicate that the account depicts another person, group, or organization in their profile to discuss, satirize, or share information about that entity. This label distinguishes these accounts to ensure they do not cause confusion for others or incorrectly imply any affiliation. These accounts must still adhere to our Authenticity policy. X does not control the selection of these labels, and users may change their PCF label at any time,” the update policy says.Users can add the PCF label to their accounts by navigating to Settings and Privacy > Your account > Account information, and then selecting Parody, commentary and fan account.X plans to make these labels mandatory for parody accounts in the future and will share details about the timeline soon, as per a report by TechCrunch.
Article Summary: Elon Musk-owned social media platform X has announced that it will begin labeling parody and satire accounts. This move aims to prevent users from mistaking posts from these accounts as genuine statements from the individuals or organisations being spoofed. X plans to make these labels mandatory for parody accounts in the future.

Article Title: Facebook parent Meta employees are said to be furious with changes in the company's LGBTQ policy
Article Text:
Meta employees criticize LGBTQ policy change

What are the changes in Meta's policy

Meta recently made controversial changes to its Hateful Conduct policy , raising concerns that the new guidelines will allow harmful content to thrive on its platforms. The tech giant has lifted restrictions on divisive and discriminatory rhetoric across its platforms – Facebook, Instagram, and Threads. The policy now permits users to engage in harmful speech, including calling gay individuals "mentally ill," referring to women as "property," and labeling entire ethnic groups as "diseases."Announced by CEO Mark Zuckerberg, the policy change is aimed to promote "free expression" by reducing restrictions on controversial topics, including gender identity and sexuality. However, the development has sparked outrage within the company.According to a 404 Media report, many employees have described the move as "unacceptable" and "appalling” in leaked internal discussions. One post by an employee on an internal Meta platform called Workplace reads “I am LGBT and Mentally Ill”. “Just to let you know that I’ll be taking time out to look after my mental health.”Employees have also expressed concern over the lack of transparency surrounding the decision, pointing out the absence of the usual internal consultations and discussions with external experts.The changes as announced by the company on Tuesday, January 7 remove prohibitions against dehumanizing language based on "protected characteristics," such as race, ethnicity, gender, and sexual orientation. Meta now allows users to compare these groups to inanimate objects, filth, and diseases like cancer. Additionally, individuals can claim that certain protected characteristics should not exist or are inferior.Protected characteristics, as defined by Meta, include race, ethnicity, national origin, disability, religion, caste, sexual orientation, sex, gender identity, and serious disease.The revised policy also eliminates Meta’s previous stance on hateful conduct creating an "environment of intimidation and exclusion" and acknowledges the potential for offline violence.
Article Summary: Meta recently made controversial changes to its Hateful Conduct policy. The tech giant has lifted restrictions on divisive and discriminatory rhetoric across its platforms – Facebook, Instagram, and Threads. The policy now permits users to engage in harmful speech, including calling gay individuals "mentally ill" and referring to women as "property"

Article Title: Supreme Court warns against websites collecting personal information: Here’s what you should do
Article Text:
What is phishing scam



SC asks phishing attack victims to change passwords

The Supreme Court registry has issued a public notice warning against fake websites pretending to be its official site. These fake websites, the advisory notice says, are trying to collect people's personal and confidential information, says a PTI report. The SC registry said “The Registry, Supreme Court of India has been made aware of a phishing attack,” adding that the fake websites have been hosted on the uniform resource locator (URL).It said, “The attackers through the URLs are soliciting personal details and confidential information. Any visitor on the above URLs is strongly advised not to share and divulge any personal and confidential information, as the same shall enable the perpetrators to steal the information.”The registry stated that this notice is for public safety and strongly advises everyone not to click on or share any links they receive without first checking if they are genuine.A phishing scam is a type of online fraud where scammers trick people into sharing sensitive information, such as passwords, credit card numbers, or personal details.They often do this by sending fake emails, messages, or links that look like they come from trusted organizations (like banks, government agencies, or popular websites). Once you click on the link or share your information, the scammers can use it for illegal activities, such as stealing money or identity theft.“Please note that the Registry, Supreme Court of India will never ask for personal information, financial details or other confidential information. Please also note that the Supreme Court of India is the registered user of the domain name www.sci.gov.in and before clicking on any URL always hover over the URL to verify the same,” it said.It advised that anyone who falls victim to a phishing attack should immediately change the passwords for all their online accounts. They should also contact their bank or credit card company to report any unauthorized access or suspicious activity.“The Registry, Supreme Court of India has taken due concern of the phishing attack and has flagged the same with law enforcement agencies, to investigate the phishing attack and bring the perpetrators to justice,” it added.
Article Summary: The Supreme Court registry has issued a public notice warning against fake websites pretending to be its official site. These fake websites, the advisory notice says, are trying to collect people's personal and confidential information. A phishing scam is a type of online fraud where scammers trick people into sharing sensitive information.

Article Title: Reliance Jio, Airtel and Vodafone-Idea want telecom department to take this 'international call' on Amazon, Netflix and others
Article Text:
Telcos vs Amazon, Netflix and others

Telecom operators are reportedly lobbying the Department of Telecommunications DoT ) to adopt the Telecom Regulatory Authority of India 's (TRAI) definition of international traffic, a change that could boost their SMS revenues by over Rs 400 crore annually.According to a report in Economic Times, the Cellular Operators Association of India (COAI), whose members include Reliance Jio Airtel and Vodafone-Idea , have sent a letter to the telecom secretary Neeraj Mittal. The letter has urged the DoT to incorporate Trai's recommendations into existing unified license agreements and upcoming authorizations. Trai recently defined international traffic as SMS messages that originate or terminate from devices, servers, or applications located outside India. COAI believes this definition will provide much-needed clarity to the industry.Experts predict that adopting this definition could generate over Rs 400 crore in additional annual SMS revenue for telcos by preventing the misclassification of international messages as domestic ones.This push follows years of dispute between telecom operators and multinational companies (MNCs), including e-commerce giants, regarding message classification. These MNCs include Amazon, Flipkart, Netflix and others.Telcos have alleged that some MNCs process international transactions from foreign servers but send SMS messages from domestic systems to avoid higher international SMS charges. While Trai has set domestic SMS rates between 0.2 and 0.5 paisa, international SMS rates are significantly higher, ranging from ₹2 to ₹5 depending on the origin country.Trai's recent recommendation clarifies that any incoming application-to-person (A2P) SMS message should be considered international if it requires the use or intervention of any device, system, or application located outside India. This move addresses the issue of various entities, including financial institutions, e-commerce firms, enterprises, cloud providers, and OTTs, using A2P messaging without revealing the SMS origin. Telcos argue that this clarity is crucial.
Article Summary: Telecom operators are reportedly lobbying the Department of Telecommunications DoT to adopt Trai's definition of international traffic. Trai recently defined international traffic as SMS messages that originate or terminate from devices, servers, or applications located outside India. Telcos argue that this clarity is crucial.

Article Title: Brazil judge who suspended Elon Musk’s X in the country has ‘warning’ for Google, Apple, Microsoft and other tech giants
Article Text:
Moraes ‘warning’ comes a day after Meta’s suspension of fact-checkers

Moraes suspended X in Brazil

Brazilian Supreme Court Justice Alexandre de Moraes has issued a strong warning to tech companies, emphasizing that compliance with Brazilian laws is mandatory for operating in the country. Moraes, who recently ordered the temporary suspension of X (formerly Twitter), owned by Elon Musk, stated that the court will not permit the monetization of hate speech.“In Brazil, (the companies) will only continue to operate if they respect Brazilian legislation, regardless of the rant of Big Tech managers,” Moraes said, as per news agency Reuters.While Moraes did not name any specific company, his remarks came shortly after Meta announced plans to discontinue its US fact-checking program and loosen restrictions on discussions surrounding controversial topics.Moraes, speaking at an event commemorating the second anniversary of the January 8 riots in Brazil, underscored the importance of respecting Brazilian legislation, regardless of the opinions of Big Tech executives.Meanwhile, Brazilian prosecutors have requested clarification from Meta regarding whether the changes to its fact-checking program in the US will also apply to Brazil. Meta has been given 30 days to respond as part of an ongoing investigation into online misinformation and violence.On August 30, 2024, Moraes ordered the suspension of X (formerly Twitter) in Brazil, accusing the platform of failing to comply with local laws requiring the appointment of a legal representative in the country.This decision resulted in a complete shutdown of X's operations in Brazil. Major tech companies like Apple and Google, along with Brazilian internet service providers (ISPs), blocked access to the platform for their users, effectively cutting off millions of Brazilians from the social media service.The suspension, initially ordered by Moraes and later unanimously upheld by a Supreme Court panel, led to a clash between Moraes and X owner Elon Musk, who criticised the judge's actions as censorship.
Article Summary: Brazilian Supreme Court Justice Alexandre de Moraes has issued a strong warning to tech companies. He stated that compliance with Brazilian laws is mandatory for operating in the country. Morae recently ordered the temporary suspension of X (formerly Twitter), owned by Elon Musk.

Article Title: Elon Musk says ‘yes’ to Google and Microsoft AI heads on this
Article Text:
Synthetic data is the way to go, says Musk

Elon Musk has joined the chorus of AI experts declaring that we've hit “peak data.” In a recent livestream, the xAI founder stated that AI models have essentially consumed all of humanity's accumulated knowledge and there’s very little real-world data left to train AI models on."We've exhausted basically the cumulative sum of human knowledge...in AI training," Musk said, adding, “That happened basically last year.”Demis Hassabis, CEO of Google DeepMind , recently cautioned that the rapid advancements in AI chatbots may be slowing down. He attributed this potential slowdown to a growing scarcity of high-quality data for training AI models. Hassabis said that tech companies have essentially ‘exhausted’ the readily available data on the internet, having already used it to train existing large language models.In fact, about a month ago, Microsoft AI chief Mustafa Suleyman talked about the use of synthetic data to train AI models because the available data is exhausted – something that OpenAI's former chief scientist, Ilya Sutskever, warned about.Musk believes the solution lies in synthetic data – data generated by AI itself. He envisions AI models creating their own training data and engaging in a “process of self-learning.”“The only way to supplement [real-world data] is with synthetic data, where the AI creates [training data],” he said.“With synthetic data … [AI] will sort of grade itself and go through this process of self-learning,” he added.This approach is already being adopted by major players like Microsoft, Meta, OpenAI, and Anthropic, who are using synthetic data to train their most advanced AI models.Google DeepMind has reportedly been using synthetic data to train AL models and it relied on this method to help train a model that can solve Olympiad-level geometry problems.In fact, the AI arm of Google recently pointed to inference-time compute – a solution to tackle the lack of data to train AI models. This technique allows AI models to tackle complex tasks by breaking them down into smaller, manageable prompts, essentially learning along the way."We’re generating vast amounts of synthetic data. That synthetic data is increasingly high quality," Suleyman told The Verge in an interview last month.
Article Summary: Elon Musk has joined the chorus of AI experts declaring that we've hit “peak data.” In a recent livestream, the xAI founder stated that AI models have essentially consumed all of humanity's accumulated knowledge. He envisions AI models creating their own training data and engaging in a “process of self- learning”

Article Title: Why restaurants across the country are up in arms against Swiggy, Zomato over 10-minute food delivery
Article Text:
What NRAI said against Swiggy and Zomato



“We are absolutely not okay with Zomato and Swiggy engaging in private labelling and selling food directly via Blinkit’s Bistro app and Swiggy’s Snacc app for quick food delivery. They have access to all our data, which they do not share with us. For us, there is complete consumer masking. We have no reason to believe they are not migrating our customers to the products they sell as private labels on their apps, whether it’s data from a tea brand, biryani, or momo. We are seriously considering taking legal action.”

“Quick commerce in food is here to stay, grow, and add more zing to the food delivery space. People want more convenience, and this will give an edge to restaurants that can adapt to it. We fully support it. However, as long as these aggregators work with restaurants and enable them to go quick, we’re fine with it. But we cannot support a model where they sell similar products themselves, effectively competing with us. This has not been allowed for even larger e-commerce players operating under the marketplace model,”

Restaurants across India are protesting against Zomato and Swiggy 's launch of standalone apps for 10-minute food delivery . The National Restaurant Association of India (NRAI) is also planning to take the issue to the Competition Commission of India (CCI). The NRAI alleges that these new apps, Bistro by Zomato-owned Blinkit and Snacc by Swiggy, amount to the companies operating private labels , which could harm existing restaurant partners. This move escalates an ongoing case the NRAI has with the CCI against the two food delivery giants, accusing them of anti-competitive practices.In a statement to the Economic Times, Sagar Daryani , NRAI president and co-founder and CEO of Wow Momo said:Food delivery platforms like Zomato and Swiggy use services like Bistro and Snacc, respectively to source food and beverages from third-party vendors and deliver them through quick-commerce dark stores. Apart from this, the companies also provide a 15-minute food delivery service by aggregating restaurants. Swiggy’s rapid food delivery service, offered under its Bolt model, now contributes to over 5% of its total food delivery orders, ET reports.Daryani added.NRAI has also urged the government to grant industry status to the food services sector, news agency PTI reports. The restaurant body cited the food services sector’s economic contributions and potential to grow into a Rs 7.76 lakh crore industry by 2028.
Article Summary: Restaurants across India are protesting against Zomato and Swiggy's launch of standalone apps for 10-minute food delivery. The National Restaurant Association of India (NRAI) is also planning to take the issue to the Competition Commission of India. NRAI alleges that these new apps amount to the companies operating private labels, which could harm existing restaurant partners.
